text:
The perfect pour of any beer from a glass
or bottle is all about getting the head just
right for overall taste and visual satisfaction.

Not only does the carbon dioxide in beer head
add its own mildly sour taste, but the froth

itself contains a wide variety of delicate
flavours that take the form of tiny molecules

that are released and detected in your nose
while drinking.

Here are five simple steps to getting it just
right -- according to science.

I have an average can of lager and I'm going
to be aiming for what many would consider

a perfectly respectable head of one inch,
with a slightly domed cap peaking just over
the surface of the glass.

The most important part of science to consider
with any pour is all about carbon dioxide

gas and how it can gather together to form
bubbles, or froth -- the scientific term for
this is 'nucleation'.

The real trick behind the Perfect Pour is
all about controlling the speed at which nucleation
occurs.

In a carbonated beverage like beer, carbon
dioxide gas is dissolved in the liquid and

forced to stay there under high pressure from
the bottle or can.

When we open the can or bottle that pressure
quickly lowers to the normal pressure around

us, and some of the carbon dioxide molecules
gathered in big enough groups can force back

the surrounding liquid and escape in the form
of a bubble.

This process of 'degasification' is why we
observe bubbles forming when we open a bottle

of beer, or any other fizzy drink for that
matter!

One thing that helps big enough groups of
CO2 molecules to gather together and form

bubbles is having hiding places in which to
accumulate away from the liquid pushing in
from all sides.

We call these places 'nucleation sites' and
they can be anything from scratches in the

liquid's container, to the surface of tiny
particles in the liquid or even other bubbles!

Now we've nailed bubbles, we can go onto the
important part -- the scientifically perfect
pour!
Step one is the big choice.

You must select your beverage and a nice clean
glass.

If your glass is dirty and scratched this
provides lots of nucleation sites for CO2

bubbles to form and can send your froth out
of control!

For a very foamy beer, you might want to give
your glass a quick rinse with cold water as

this can effectively mask some of those nucleation
sites and reduce the number of bubbles forming.
And thus you've controlled the head!
Step two is the tilt.

Hold your glass at a 45 degree angle and gently
pour the beer so that there is a small gap

between the interior of the glass and the
top of your can or bottle.

The smooth flow of beer ensures that there's
less chance of air getting in the liquid and

providing nucleation sites for CO2 bubbles
to form.

The 45 degree angle is shallow enough to ensure
that the beer flows smoothly down the glass

without making a big 'splash' at the bottom,
but steep enough to make sure there is no

'up-splash' when liquid initially hits the
glass.

Tilting the glass or can too sharply means
that air can enter it as it tries to equalise
the pressure inside.

This can result in lots more nucleation sites
and results in a very frothy brew.
Step three, straightening up.

When the beer reaches the lip of the glass,
gently halt pouring and start to straighten.

Now a nice headless pour has been achieved
we can get ready to intentionally produce
that glorious foam.
Step four, the long pour.

Pour your beer from above into the centre
of the glass and watch the creamy head form

until it just bows up over the lip of the
glass.

The long pour incorporates air into the beer
and allows plenty of nucleation sites for
CO2 bubbles to form.

Those bubbles gather together and bring with
them lots of stabilising molecules from inside

the beer to form a perfect and relatively
long lasting foam.
Step five, don't lose your head!

Whether you like it or not, your beer head
is contributing many delicate flavours to
the overall taste of your beer.

So instead of sipping take measured mouthfuls
to ensure you don't slurp away all that carefully

constructed foam and ruin the steady release
of aromas as you drink.

All beer heads are unstable which means they
will gradually disappear as the bubbles burst.

In order to maintain them and that steady
release of beery aromas, many manufacturers

have included laser etched nucleation sites
on the bottom of their glasses which ensures

a nice steady release of bubbles throughout
your pint experience.

Remember that every beer is different so some
may need more or less straight and tilted
pouring to achieve the desired effect.

The important point to remember is that you
should enjoy with company and drink as responsibly
as possible.
Cheers!
